article:
]]

A 'breakfast cereal' (or just 'cereal') is a food made from processed grains
that is often eaten with the first meal of the day. It is often eaten cold,
usually mixed with milk (e.g. cow's milk, soy milk, rice milk, almond milk),
juice, water, or yogurt, and sometimes fruit, but may be eaten dry. Some
companies promote their products for the health benefits from eating oat-based
and high-fiber cereals. Cereals may be fortified with vitamins. Some cereals are
made with high sugar content. Many breakfast cereals are produced via extrusion.

The breakfast cereal industry has gross profit margins of 40-45%, {{Cite
news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2006/dec/28/food.usnews |title=How
constipation cure became huge business |work=The Guardian |accessdate=2008-04-20
|last=Lawrence |first=Felicity
| location=London date=2006-12-28
}}  90% penetration in some markets, {{Cite web
|url=http://www.researchandmarkets.com/reports/3509 |title=Breakfast Cereals
Market Report - Market Research Reports - Research and Markets |publisher=Key
Note Publications Ltd |accessdate=2008-04-20 |last= |first= }}  and steady
and continued growth throughout its history. [http://www.mmc.gov.uk/rep_pub-
/reports/1970_1975/fulltext/067c01.pdf "Breakfast Cereals: A Report on the
Supply of Ready Cooked Breakfast Cereal Foods"], The Monopolies C omission, 20
February 1973 with milk.]]
